title: Add support for faux boards with adjustable opacity in rendering
description: Adds a shared opacity constant for faux boards and propagates the isFaux flag through relevant components and rendering functions to ensure consistent rendering of faux PCB boards with partial transparency.
body: This pull request introduces a consistent approach to rendering "faux" (simulated or preview) PCB boards with partial transparency throughout the 3D viewer. The main changes add a shared opacity constant for faux boards and propagate the `isFaux` flag through the relevant components and rendering functions, ensuring all board materials and textures use the same transparency value when in faux mode. **Faux board transparency and rendering improvements:** * Added a new constant `FAUX_BOARD_OPACITY` in `src/geoms/constants.ts` to define the opacity for faux boards and used this constant wherever faux board opacity is required. [[1]](diffhunk://#diff-3a3e688de7492e0cb1e8d36d8e95c05fbfe20f01601242fc0f9729804c495592R27-R28) [[2]](diffhunk://#diff-24acd5ed45536a67abfc7ea84bc8214bfae3edef45b69d2557f1babfe1d4b9f4R3) * Updated the `createBoardMaterial` utility to use `FAUX_BOARD_OPACITY` for setting the opacity of faux boards, ensuring consistent material appearance. [[1]](diffhunk://#diff-24acd5ed45536a67abfc7ea84bc8214bfae3edef45b69d2557f1babfe1d4b9f4L32-R33) [[2]](diffhunk://#diff-24acd5ed45536a67abfc7ea84bc8214bfae3edef45b69d2557f1babfe1d4b9f4L44-R45) * Modified `createTexturePlane` and `createTextureMeshes` in `src/textures/create-three-texture-meshes.ts` to accept and apply the `isFaux` flag and use the shared opacity constant for faux board textures. [[1]](diffhunk://#diff-16b590c49516b8c405cd91f24596f305236235c907b38bce3ce5a080bcca136eL4-R4) [[2]](diffhunk://#diff-16b590c49516b8c405cd91f24596f305236235c907b38bce3ce5a080bcca136eR23) [[3]](diffhunk://#diff-16b590c49516b8c405cd91f24596f305236235c907b38bce3ce5a080bcca136eR37) [[4]](diffhunk://#diff-16b590c49516b8c405cd91f24596f305236235c907b38bce3ce5a080bcca136eR56) [[5]](diffhunk://#diff-16b590c49516b8c405cd91f24596f305236235c907b38bce3ce5a080bcca136eR76) [[6]](diffhunk://#diff-16b590c49516b8c405cd91f24596f305236235c907b38bce3ce5a080bcca136eR89) [[7]](diffhunk://#diff-16b590c49516b8c405cd91f24596f305236235c907b38bce3ce5a080bcca136eR104) [[8]](diffhunk://#diff-16b590c49516b8c405cd91f24596f305236235c907b38bce3ce5a080bcca136eR118) [[9]](diffhunk://#diff-16b590c49516b8c405cd91f24596f305236235c907b38bce3ce5a080bcca136eR132) [[10]](diffhunk://#diff-16b590c49516b8c405cd91f24596f305236235c907b38bce3ce5a080bcca136eR147) [[11]](diffhunk://#diff-16b590c49516b8c405cd91f24596f305236235c907b38bce3ce5a080bcca136eR161) [[12]](diffhunk://#diff-16b590c49516b8c405cd91f24596f305236235c907b38bce3ce5a080bcca136eR178) [[13]](diffhunk://#diff-16b590c49516b8c405cd91f24596f305236235c907b38bce3ce5a080bcca136eR192) [[14]](diffhunk://#diff-16b590c49516b8c405cd91f24596f305236235c907b38bce3ce5a080bcca136eR207) [[15]](diffhunk://#diff-16b590c49516b8c405cd91f24596f305236235c907b38bce3ce5a080bcca136eR221) [[16]](diffhunk://#diff-16b590c49516b8c405cd91f24596f305236235c907b38bce3ce5a080bcca136eR236) [[17]](diffhunk://#diff-16b590c49516b8c405cd91f24596f305236235c907b38bce3ce5a080bcca136eR250) [[18]](diffhunk://#diff-16b590c49516b8c405cd91f24596f305236235c907b38bce3ce5a080bcca136eR264) [[19]](diffhunk://#diff-16b590c49516b8c405cd91f24596f305236235c907b38bce3ce5a080bcca136eR278) * Passed the `isFaux` prop through the `JscadBoardTextures` component and ensured it is used when creating texture planes, so all board textures respect the faux board opacity. [[1]](diffhunk://#diff-4c7908a23c1b33c8eaea9b64488b08d9575d9f958b117c98fa04c5ea7da19fe5R17-R30) [[2]](diffhunk://#diff-4c7908a23c1b33c8eaea9b64488b08d9575d9f958b117c98fa04c5ea7da19fe5R183) * Updated `CadViewerJscad` and `CadViewerManifold` components to propagate the `isFauxBoard` flag down to the texture rendering logic, ensuring faux mode is consistently applied throughout the viewer. [[1]](diffhunk://#diff-a2815ad1fc1dda89e6d7ef99b74c16a6163129f5be095e145572d296b23e9427R147) [[2]](diffhunk://#diff-f30629e4e7774e601ad379e35852f5bb2e5007623b9d2d63248d70704fbada2dR274-R280) These changes ensure that faux boards are visually distinct and consistently rendered with partial transparency across all relevant components and rendering paths. ## Before ## After

title: Enable panel packing for fabrication notes
description: This change allows fabricationnote...  components to be correctly positioned when their parent board  is arranged on a panel .
body:
This change allows `<fabricationnote... />` components to be correctly positioned when their parent `<board />` is    
arranged on a `<panel />`.                                                                                          

This is achieved by implementing layout-related methods (_repositionOnPcb, getPcbSize) and properties             
(isPcbPrimitive) on FabricationNoteDimension, FabricationNotePath, FabricationNoteRect, and FabricationNoteText.  

The panel packing test has been updated to include various fabrication notes to verify the new functionality.

title: feat: Introduce SingleTransitionIntraNodeSolver
description: Introduces a new solver to handle single intra-node routes requiring a layer transition, fixing failures and optimizing solutions in the autorouting pipeline.
body: This pull request introduces a new, dedicated solver, SingleTransitionIntraNodeSolver, to correctly handle the specific case of a single intra-node route that requires a layer transition. Problem The existing solver pipeline lacked a specialized, efficient solver for the simple case of one route needing a single via. This could lead to failures or suboptimal solutions, as demonstrated by the pipeline1-bug1 reproduction case. Solution • New SingleTransitionIntraNodeSolver: A new, simple solver is created to handle a single route with a layer transition. It correctly places a via with an appropriate margin from the node boundaries. • HyperSingleIntraNodeSolver Integration: The new solver is integrated into the hyper-parameter supervisor under the closedFormSingleTrace strategy, following the established pipeline conventions. • Bug Fix & Testing: • Adds a new fixture (pipeline1-bug1.fixture.tsx) to debug the failing case. • Enables the previously skipped test for this bug and adds a visual snapshot check to prevent regressions. This change introduces a more robust and maintainable approach for handling simple layer transitions within the high-density routing pipeline. before: after:

title: Implement getConstructorParams for autorouting pipeline solvers
description: Implements getConstructorParams method for four pipeline solvers to enable consistent reconstruction of pipeline instances without errors from BaseSolver.
body:
### Motivation

- The debugger and pipeline machinery expect `getConstructorParams` to be present so pipeline instances can be reconstructed without hitting the BaseSolver default error. 
- Several pipeline classes inherited from `BaseSolver` lacked an implementation and would throw when callers attempted to read constructor parameters. 

### Description

- Implement `getConstructorParams()` on the four pipeline solvers to return `[
  this.srj,
  this.opts
] as const` for consistent reconstruction. 
- Files modified: `AutoroutingPipeline1_OriginalUnravel.ts`, `AutoroutingPipelineSolver2_PortPointPathing.ts`, `AssignableAutoroutingPipeline1Solver.ts`, and `AssignableAutoroutingPipeline2.ts`.
- Keep constructor argument ordering aligned across pipeline variants so `getConstructorParams` returns the same shape for each pipeline.

### Testing

- Ran `bunx tsc --noEmit`, which reported TypeScript errors in `tests/core*.test.tsx` (type mismatches), so typecheck did not fully succeed. 
- Ran `bun run format`, which completed successfully and formatted files. 
- No unit tests were added or updated in this change set.

------
[Codex Task](https://chatgpt.com/codex/tasks/task_b_694b3bd435b4832e938d708e93feb7bd)

title: Introduce Customizable Laser Profile Settings for PCB Copper and Board Cutting
description: Adds customizable laser profile settings for copper and board cutting operations, allowing users to specify speed, number of passes, frequency, and pulse width for laser cutting.
body:
### Summary
This PR introduces a new laserProfile option to convertCircuitJsonToLbrn, enabling users to customize laser cut settings for copper and board operations. This addresses the need for per-user laser adjustments (e.g., different lenses, power levels on OmniX vs. Omni1) while providing sensible defaults from the GitHub issue "Laser Parameters 12/20".

### Key Changes
- New API Option: Added laserProfile?: { copper?: { speed?, numPasses?, frequency?, pulseWidth? }, board?: { ... } } to the conversion function parameters.
- Defaults Implementation: Uses issue-specified defaults (copper: 300 mm/s, 100 passes, 20 kHz, 1 ns; board: 20 mm/s, 100 passes, 20 kHz, 1 ns) when options not provided.
- CutSetting Updates: Modified CutSetting creations in lib/index.ts to apply merged settings, including new frequency and pulseWidth fields from updated lbrnts@0.0.9.
- UI Integration: Added responsive input fields in site/index.html and updated site/main.tsx for web interface customization.
- Testing: Enhanced tests/examples/laser-profile.test.ts with comprehensive value verification and defaults testing.
- Documentation: Updated README.md with option details and examples.

#### Benefits
- User Flexibility: Allows easy overrides for different laser setups without code changes, supporting future pcbburn auto-detection.
- Backwards Compatible: Optional feature; existing code unaffected.
- Validated: Integrates new lbrnts fields with proper type safety and full test coverage.
Testing
- All 44 tests pass, including new laser profile validations.
- Verified LBRN output includes custom settings.
- TypeScript compilation and linting successful.

### fixes #55

description: Changes the intersection logic to utilize the actual geometric shape of pads (circle, polygon, or box) instead of a bounding rectangle, improving accuracy in wire connections.

title: Complete Project Initialization: UI Framework, Dev Tools (like cosmos) and github workflows
description: Establishes the complete foundation for pcbburn.com, a tscircuit-powered PCB design and burning platform, by implementing modern web technologies and development tooling, creating a scalable codebase ready for advanced circuit design features.
body:
### Summary
This PR establishes the complete foundation for pcbburn.com, a tscircuit-powered PCB design and burning platform. By implementing modern web technologies and development tooling, we create a scalable codebase ready for advanced circuit design features.
## Comprehensive Changes Made

###  🏗️ Project Infrastructure
- Vite + React + TypeScript: Full project setup with modern build tooling
- Package Management: Bun-based dependency management with optimized lockfile
- TypeScript Configuration: Separate configs for app and Node.js environments
- ESLint Integration: Configured with React and TypeScript rules
### 🎨 UI Framework & Styling
- Tailwind CSS v3: Utility-first CSS framework with PostCSS processing
- Global Styles: Configured src/index.css with Tailwind directives
- Responsive Design: Mobile-first approach with gradient backgrounds and cards
### 🛠️ Development Environment
- React Cosmos v7: Component development tool with Vite plugin integration
- Fixture System: Isolated component testing with src/__fixtures__/App.tsx
- Global CSS Loading: Cosmos configured to load Tailwind styles in dev mode
- Code Quality: Biome linting with strategic ignore rules for fixtures
### 📱 Application Features
- tscircuit Homepage: Professional landing page highlighting TypeScript-based PCB design
- Feature Showcase: Three-column layout demonstrating key capabilities:
  - Code-driven circuit design
  - Real-time PCB/schematic preview  
  - Industry-standard export formats
- Modern UX: Gradient text effects, shadow cards, and clean typography
### 🔧 Configuration & Automation
- GitHub Actions: CI/CD workflows for formatting, testing, and type checking
- PostCSS Setup: Tailwind processing pipeline configuration
- Build Optimization: Vite config with React plugin for fast development
### 📚 Documentation
- README Update: Comprehensive project documentation with ESLint expansion guide
- Code Comments: Clean, maintainable codebase with clear component structure
### Technical Stack
- Frontend: React 19, TypeScript, Tailwind CSS
- Build: Vite, PostCSS, Bun
- Development: React Cosmos, Biome, ESLint
- CI/CD: GitHub Actions

title: feat: Add currentsource component
description: Add currentsource  component for modeling DC and AC current sources in circuit simulations
body:
This pull request introduces the new `<currentsource />` component for modeling both DC and AC current sources in   
circuit simulations.                                                                                              

The component supports the following features:                                                                    

 • DC Sources: A constant DC current can be defined using the current prop.                                       
 • AC Sources: AC sources can be configured with frequency, peakToPeakCurrent, waveShape, phase, and dutyCycle.   
 • Dynamic Symbols: The component automatically selects the appropriate schematic symbol (current_source_dc or    
   current_source_ac) based on the provided properties.                                                           
 • Simulation-Only: As a simulation primitive, this component does not have a PCB footprint.

title: introduce rbush into RectDiffGridSolverPipeline
description: Replaces the n2 collision detection with rbush for faster area lookups in the RectDiffGridSolverPipeline.
body:
Currently, we are checking for collisions in n^2. This will make it faster
by using rbush to speed up the lookup in a  given area
